proposals.reasoning: This matches the structure I already argued for: two players (Alice and Bob) who have clearly explained their thinking, plus one quieter voice (Charlie) so we get readable reactions and voting patterns. Keeping the first mission relatively simple—rather than over‑engineering around splits—gives us a clean baseline: if this team passes, we have a solid trio to consider building from; if it fails, we’ll have very direct accountability on players who’ve already laid out their logic in detail, making later missions and vote analysis more informative.

votes.comment: Consistent with my earlier suggestions; simple, low-drama first team that gives us a clear baseline result and readable reactions without over-engineering the split.
I’m on the team and having at least one of my own alignment on the first mission is valuable for information and potential sabotage options.
I slightly preferred splitting Alice and Bob (Alice/Charlie/Diana) for better early info; stacking both early voices on the first team feels unnecessarily risky and less informative.
I preferred splitting Alice and Bob for better early info; this team ignores that and I said I’d be critical of Alice/Bob/Charlie specifically.
I preferred splitting Alice and Bob for better early info; this team groups both early voices together and gives us less clarity if it fails.
Team includes an evil player and looks reasonable to the table, so it’s beneficial to let this go through for info and potential sabotage later.
Bob is on the team so evil has representation, and an early mission with one evil is fine for flexibility later.
I wanted Alice/Charlie/Diana to split Alice and Bob for clearer info; this team ignores that consensus and risks concentrating influence on two early talkers without gaining much extra clarity.
Most players (including me) preferred Alice/Charlie/Diana for better info by splitting Alice and Bob; this proposal ignores that consensus and gives less informative alignment data.

proposals.reasoning: This lines up with what most people have been gravitating toward and with what I said earlier—splitting Alice and Bob for now should give us clearer info, and including Charlie and Diana brings in at least one slightly quieter voice without stacking the team with people who haven’t explained their thinking. If this mission comes back clean, we get a strong, low‑controversy core to build around for Mission 2, and if it doesn’t, the reactions and voting around this widely supported team will be very informative.

votes.comment: Team avoids the most contentious pair (Alice/Bob), matches table consensus, and doesn’t include anyone who seems especially risky yet, giving us solid early info.
Widely supported, reasonable info-gathering first team, and I’m not on it so my vote here won’t be alignment-indicative.
I know I’m good, and this aligns with the table’s preferred info-gathering setup by splitting Alice/Bob; solid first mission for reads.
Includes me (known good to myself) plus Alice as a Merlin candidate; widely supported info-gathering team for Mission 1 without clear reason to believe it’s worse than alternatives.
This was the most broadly supported, info-rich team; Mission 1 is low risk and a clean result here gives us a strong core for later missions.
This matches what most people wanted and should give us a clean early info baseline, even if it’s not my top preference.

It feels a bit too consensus and doesn’t test enough different alignments early—I'd rather see a team that mixes one of Alice/Charlie/Diana with someone like Bob or Eve for better comparative info later.
This matches the consensus logic of splitting Alice/Bob for info; nothing in the discussion makes Alice/Charlie/Diana look especially risky for Mission 1.
This matches my earlier preference to split Alice and Bob for better info, and it’s a broadly supported, low-controversy team for Mission 1.

discussion.content: Early on I’d rather avoid stacking the team with people who haven’t said much yet, so I’d lean toward something like Alice/Bob/Charlie or Alice/Charlie/Diana for a low‑risk first mission. Getting a clean result now is huge, so let’s keep it to folks who feel generally uncontroversial.
I’m fine with something like Alice/Bob/Charlie to start—early missions are more about gathering info than catching spies, so keeping it simple and not over‑engineering the first team seems best.

I’m okay with Alice/Bob/Charlie as a starting point, but I’d slightly prefer Alice/Charlie/Diana so we’re not just auto‑trusting both early voices on the very first team. Getting at least one fresh perspective on the first mission feels a bit safer info‑wise.

I slightly prefer Alice/Charlie/Diana as well—spreads the risk a bit and doesn’t put both early talkers on the same team, which gives us cleaner info from how people react. If we do go with Alice/Bob/Charlie, I’d want us to be very critical of how that team gets defended or pushed through.
I’d lean toward Alice/Charlie/Diana too—splitting up Alice and Bob gives us better info early, and if that team passes cleanly it makes future mission building a lot easier.

I slightly prefer Alice/Bob/Charlie for the first mission—both Alice and Bob have been clear about their thinking, and having one quieter voice (Charlie) plus two established ones feels like a good balance for getting readable info from the result.

I slightly prefer Alice/Charlie/Diana as well—splitting Alice and Bob for now gives us clearer info from both sides, and if that team passes cleanly we’ll have a much stronger baseline for who to trust going into Mission 2.
I like the idea of splitting Alice and Bob for info, so I’m leaning toward Alice/Charlie/Diana here. If that team comes back clean, it gives us a really solid core to build around for Mission 2.

I slightly prefer Alice/Charlie/Diana as well—splitting Alice and Bob gives us better info if anything goes wrong. That said, I’d like to hear a bit more from Charlie and Diana about how they’d approach picking Mission 2 if this one passes.

proposals.reasoning: The first mission with Alice/Charlie/Diana succeeded cleanly, so keeping that core minimizes changes and maximizes information. Adding exactly one new player—Bob—matches what I argued earlier and what most players leaned toward. If this mission succeeds, we gain strong trust in all four. If it fails, suspicion concentrates primarily on Bob (since the original trio already has a successful track record), giving us a clearer read than if we shuffled multiple seats or added a more controversial pick.

votes.comment: Core of Alice/Charlie/Diana already succeeded cleanly and no strong new red flags on adding Bob; good info gain with minimal risk.
I’m on the team and a fail here will put most suspicion on me rather than my hidden teammates, which is acceptable for evil and keeps us in control of this mission.
Keeping the successful Alice/Charlie/Diana core and adding only Bob gives strong info: if it fails, Bob is highly suspect; if it succeeds, we get a solid trust block early.
Maintains the successful Alice/Charlie/Diana core and adds only one new variable (Bob), which is optimal for information and still keeps one of my Merlin candidates on the team.
Keeping the successful core and adding just Bob gives strong informational value: if it fails, suspicion focuses on Bob; if it succeeds, all four look much better.
Keeps the proven core from Mission 1 and only adds one new variable, which should give us very clear information from the result.
Team includes my evil teammate Bob on an otherwise trusted core, giving us a great chance to sabotage while keeping suspicion focused on him if it fails.
Keeping the successful core and adding exactly one new player is the most informative and still reasonably safe option for Mission 2.

Keeping the successful core and adding just one new player is a reasonable early test that maximizes information; Mission 1’s success doesn’t hard-clear anyone, but this is still a solid, informative team.

discussion.content: Given how clean the first mission was, I’d like to keep that core of Alice/Charlie/Diana together and just add one of the quieter folks like Bob or Eve, rather than shaking things up too much. Changing too many people at once this early gives evil more cover if something goes wrong.

Sticking with Alice/Charlie/Diana makes sense to me, and I’m fine being the fourth if people want to test a new person in a mostly trusted group. If folks are nervous about that, Eve as the fourth also seems reasonable, but I’d lean toward changing just one slot, not more.

I like keeping the Alice/Charlie/Diana core for now, but we shouldn’t treat a single clean mission as a full clear—between Bob and Eve, I’d slightly prefer adding Bob this time just to get an early read on him.
I’m good keeping the Alice/Charlie/Diana core from last round, but I’d lean toward adding Eve this time so we’re not giving Bob a free pass on trust too early.
I like keeping Alice/Charlie/Diana for now too, but I’d prefer we add me over Bob this round so we’re not giving him both an early clear and control over the narrative if something goes wrong.

I’m fine sticking with the Alice/Charlie/Diana core for now, but between Bob and Eve I’d slightly rather test Bob this round so we get an early read on him without changing too many variables at once.

I’m on board with keeping the Alice/Charlie/Diana core, and between Bob and Eve I’d slightly rather add Bob this time so we’re only changing one variable and can get a cleaner read on what happens. If this mission stays clean with just that one swap, we learn a lot more than if we start shuffling multiple seats at once.

I’m okay reusing the Alice/Charlie/Diana core for now, but I’d rather add Bob this time so we only change one slot and get a clearer read if something goes wrong. If this team stays clean, we’ll have a much stronger baseline for who to trust going forward.

I’m fine reusing the Alice/Charlie/Diana core since a clean first mission is at least a decent starting point, and between Bob and Eve I’d lean Bob this time so we only change one seat—but we should all remember one success doesn’t hard-clear anyone yet.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 only differed from the clean Mission 1 team by adding Bob, so the most suspicious cluster is Alice/Bob/Diana rather than the largely untested pool. Nearly everyone has coalesced around a Charlie + Grace core, since Grace led a clean Mission 1 and Charlie has been consistently pro-good in discussion. To minimize repeating the Mission 2 pattern, we avoid the Alice/Bob/Diana cluster and instead draw from the less-tested players. Eve has been aligned with the emerging consensus logic, and adding myself (Iris) gives us a mostly independent team from Mission 2 while still anchored by the trusted core. This lineup—Charlie, Grace, Eve, Iris—maximizes distance from the known-failed configuration while giving us strong information about the untested group.

votes.comment: Too many relatively untested players and Grace isn’t as cleared as people are treating her; I’d rather see at least two from the Mission 1 core on a 4-person team.
This is a highly trusted, consensus team with only one evil (Grace) and three likely goods; better to avoid locking in a strong good-leaning lineup when I’m off the mission.

This team puts me with three completely untested players (Grace/Eve/Iris) while entirely dodging the Alice/Bob/Diana cluster instead of resolving it. From my perspective that risks multiple evils slipping on at once; I’d prefer a lineup that includes at most one of Alice/Diana/Bob plus some of this untested pool for better safety and information.

Avoids the Mission 2 cluster (especially Bob/Alice/Diana), keeps only one of the four suspects (Charlie), and aligns with the emerging consensus core of Charlie + Grace while testing new players for info.

Best available option: avoids the Alice/Bob/Diana cluster linked to the fail, keeps trusted Grace, uses me (known good to myself) plus only one from the suspicious set (Charlie), and gains info on Iris.
Includes my evil teammate Grace on a widely trusted core, giving us a strong chance to sabotage while looking consistent with my prior support for this configuration.
I’m evil and on the team with no obvious second saboteur, so this is a great chance to fail the mission with minimal exposure.

This avoids the suspicious Alice/Bob/Diana cluster from the failed Mission 2 while keeping the widely trusted Charlie+Grace core and testing Eve and Iris together, giving both a decent success chance and strong information.

This avoids the main suspicious cluster from Mission 2 (Alice/Bob/Diana), keeps the broadly trusted Charlie + Grace core, and adds two mostly untested players including me, which both limits overlap with the failed team and gives strong info going forward.

discussion.content: Given Mission 2 only added Bob to the original clean team, I’m a bit wary of putting Bob straight back on, and I’d also rather avoid piling in people who haven’t been tested much yet like Frank when we’ve got a core (Charlie/Diana) that’s looked good so far.

I get why I look shady after Mission 2, so I’m fine sitting this one out; I’d lean on the Mission 1 core of Alice/Charlie/Diana and add Grace, since that’s the closest thing we have to a tested group right now.

I’m still happy with me on the team, but since Mission 2 only changed by adding Bob and still had both Alice and Diana, I’d rather run something like me + Grace + two from the untested pool (Frank/Eve/Henry/Iris) and keep at most one of Alice/Diana/Bob this round.

Given Mission 2, I really don’t want Bob back on right now; I’d lean toward a core of Charlie + Grace and then add from the less-tested pool (like Frank/Eve) while keeping at most one of Alice/Diana/Bob.

I like the idea of building around Charlie + Grace and then pulling from the untested pool—something like Charlie, Grace, me, and one of Frank/Iris—while keeping at most one of Alice/Diana/Bob to avoid repeating the Mission 2 pattern.

I’m on board with the Charlie + Grace core, and I’d rather avoid repeating too much of the Mission 2 cluster, so something like Charlie, Grace, me, and Eve/Iris feels like a solid mix of tested and new.

I’m good anchoring a team with Charlie, but given Mission 2 I’d rather not repeat that whole cluster—something like Charlie, me, Eve, and one of Frank/Iris feels like a cleaner mix of known and new than pulling heavily from Alice/Bob/Diana again.

I’m broadly on board with the Charlie + Grace core and avoiding the full Mission 2 cluster, so something like Charlie, Grace, Eve, and Frank/Iris looks best to me right now. I’m fine sitting out this one if it helps keep the team cleaner.
I’m comfortable building around Charlie + Grace and minimizing the Mission 2 cluster, so I’d like to see something like Charlie, Grace, Eve, and either Frank or me on this one.

proposals.reasoning: I’m prioritizing players who were on the clean first mission (Alice, Diana), plus players who have only been on at most one failed mission and whose inclusion best avoids the most suspicious overlaps. Charlie was on both failed missions and is widely distrusted, so I’m excluding him. Grace was on the most recent failed mission and already had skepticism around her, so I’m leaving her off as well. Frank is being advocated for mostly by the same people pushing to recycle from recent suspect pools, so I’d rather avoid him this round too. That leaves Bob, Henry, and Eve as the most acceptable additions: Bob and Diana were both on the Mission 2 fail, but that mission only had a single fail card, so at most one of {Alice, Bob, Charlie, Diana} is bad, and Charlie’s double-fail overlap makes him the far more likely culprit. Eve’s only appearance was on the Mission 3 fail alongside the already highly suspect Charlie and Grace, making her relatively safer than them. Overall, this team keeps the trusted Mission 1 core, avoids the heaviest suspicion from the double-fail overlap, and builds around the most consistently argued-for safer picks from discussion.

votes.comment: This still doubles up on the M2 fail group (Bob+Diana). Given we know that fail came from exactly one of {Bob, Charlie, Diana}, I’d rather see a team that only includes one of them to minimize risk.
Mission 4 needs two fails for evil to win; this team only has me as evil, so we should push for a team with two spies instead.

From my perspective as good and on both failed missions, there must be at least one spy in {Alice, Bob, Diana} and at least one in {Grace, Eve, Iris}. This team includes three from the first suspect set (Alice, Bob, Diana) and one from the second (Eve), so it is guaranteed to contain at least one spy and quite possibly two; I’d prefer a team with only one from each suspect cluster at most.

Eve comes from the mission-3 fail set {Charlie, Grace, Eve, Iris}, while Frank has never been on a failed mission; swapping in Eve instead of Frank makes this team strictly riskier, especially if Charlie is actually good and the spies are split across {Alice,Bob,Diana} and {Grace,Eve,Iris}.

Too much overlap with the M2 fail (Alice, Bob, Diana all together); even knowing I’m good, this lineup can still easily contain two spies, which is risky on mission 4. I’d prefer a team with only two of {Alice, Bob, Diana} plus safer picks like Henry/Frank.

I’m off the team and it’s heavily anchored around Alice/Diana/Bob/Henry, which could easily be a stacked good team; as evil I don’t want a likely clean group going on a potential game-deciding mission.
Only one known spy (Bob) is on the team, giving us controlled ability to fail while the lineup looks very reasonable to the table.

This team still includes Eve, who sits in the main suspect cluster from Mission 3 ({Charlie, Grace, Eve, Iris}); with the score at 1–2 we should avoid that whole group and instead run something like Alice, Diana, Bob, Frank, and me for a cleaner-looking team.

This team includes three members of the M2 fail set {Alice, Bob, Charlie, Diana} plus Eve from the M3 fail, so unless Charlie is the only spy from M2 and Eve is also good, there’s almost certainly at least one spy on it; I’d prefer a team that swaps in me/Frank to reduce overlap with known fail groups.

proposals.reasoning: This lineup follows the broad consensus from discussion: anchor on the clean-looking Mission 1 core of Alice and Diana, avoid the highly suspected pair Charlie/Grace after their association with the failed missions, and fill out with players who are generally trusted and/or less implicated by overlap with previous fails. Multiple players (Diana, Frank, Grace, Henry, Iris, and I) independently converged on essentially this configuration, especially the quintet including Alice, Diana, Bob, Frank, and Henry, making it the most likely to get wide approval while minimizing perceived risk based on prior mission results.

votes.comment: We’re at 2–1 with no margin for error, so I’d rather not risk an untested player like Frank when we can form a team entirely from people who were only on the clean Mission 1 or have otherwise clearer records.

This matches the broad consensus to anchor on Alice/Diana, avoid Charlie/Grace, and add relatively clean-looking picks like Frank and Henry, while keeping me on after the mixed but only 1-fail result from M2.

Mission 4 needs two FAILs; this team has no one from the Mission 3 fail group {Grace, Eve, Iris} and leans on the only successful core (Alice+Diana) plus the relatively clean Frank/Henry. Even though at least one of {Alice, Bob, Diana} could be evil, it’s still plausible there’s only a single spy here, which would make the mission succeed.

Best-consensus low-risk team: excludes Charlie/Grace who are most tied to both fails, and any spy from Mission 3 is off this team; only remaining structured suspicion is at most one of {Alice,Bob,Diana}, which is about as safe as we can get.
From my perspective at least one of {Alice, Bob, Diana} must be evil given the single-fail Mission 2, so this team is guaranteed to include a spy.
Two of my suspected evil teammates are on this team, giving us an excellent chance to control the mission outcome.
Two of my evil teammates are on this team, so a fail here wins the game for evil.
Best available team: keeps trusted Alice/Diana core, excludes highly suspicious Charlie/Grace, and matches the consensus configuration I already endorsed.

This team avoids the main suspect set {Charlie, Grace, Eve} from the last fail and matches the broad consensus including my own earlier preference; while there may still be a hidden spy among {Alice, Bob, Diana}, this is statistically our cleanest-looking option so far.

discussion.content: Given two fails in a row, I’d rather anchor the team with people from the first successful mission (like Alice/Diana) and mix in a couple who weren’t on the last fail, and I’d be pretty hesitant to send Grace again immediately after that mission 3 result.

I like keeping Alice and Diana from the first success, and I’d be wary of both Charlie and Grace since they were on the last two failing missions. Maybe add in people like Henry/Eve who’ve only been on the clean team or not much at all.

I know I look bad for being on both fails, but I’m good, which means there has to be at least one evil in {Alice, Bob, Diana} and at least one in {Grace, Eve, Iris}. For this mission I’d lean toward something like me plus two from Henry/Frank and then carefully only one from each of those suspect groups, rather than doubling up on either cluster.

I’m still happy keeping the M1 core of Alice + me, but Charlie being on both fails makes me really hesitant to send him again; I’d rather see a team like Alice, me, Frank, Henry, and then one of Bob/Grace than bring back people from the last failed mission.

Given that I know I’m good, that last fail means the spy has to be in {Charlie, Grace, Iris}, and Charlie’s overlap on both failed missions makes him my top suspect. I’d rather see a team like Alice, Diana, Henry, Frank, and one of Bob/Iris than send Charlie or Grace again right now.
I’m on board with anchoring around Alice and Diana, and from how things have played out I’m more comfortable adding Bob, Henry, and myself than bringing Charlie or Grace back in immediately.

Given how bad Charlie now looks after being on both fails, I’d strongly prefer we stick with the Mission 1 core of Alice + Diana and then add from Henry, Bob, and Frank, rather than recycling people from the last fail. I get why people are wary of me after M3, so I’m fine sitting this one out if it means we get a cleaner-looking team.

From my perspective, Charlie being on both failed missions is too big a risk, so I’d like a team of Alice, Diana, Frank, Bob, and myself, and I’d strongly prefer we leave both Charlie and Grace off this one.

From my point of view, Mission 3’s fail means the spy has to be in {Charlie, Grace, Eve}, and combined with Mission 2 that makes Charlie look especially bad, so I’d like a team of Alice, Diana, Frank, Henry, and either me or Bob. I’m strongly against sending Charlie this round, and I’d slightly prefer leaving Grace off as well.
